transcripts.text: I don't know what web browser most people use for social media but I use Chrome.  Chrome is fitted with this button here called a back button.  That way if you see something that you find offensive you can click on it and voila problem solved.  Seems that most other browsers have replaced the back button with this.  And once you hit it, the author of the offending remark gets canvassed by the Thought Police, as exampled by this week's featured video.  For once, I'll keep my commentary brief as the contents of the video speak for itself, and I'm sure this is just one of many Orwellian instances yet to come, but I can't resist highlighting the multiple reasons that the police give for being on this man's doorstep.

I've been asked to come speak to you to make you aware, okay, that your comments are visible online.  I've just been asked to come and remind you about the use of forums and social media, etc.  We're just here to keep the peace, aren't we?  I'm not here for any other reason than to have a chat with you, that's all.

the true reason the police are there is obvious as a means to intimidate to give the impression that this man has committed a criminal offence in the hope that they are never pushed to state what the offence actually is because there isn't one.  the officers claim that they were told to make the visit by their inspector which again backs up how willing the police are to act as service droids, doing the political bidding of their masters without ever stopping to think of the legality of their actions, let alone the moral implications or the attack on free speech.

I just want to get this home video because you're recording as well, aren't you?  I am, yeah.  Yeah, right.  So you're saying that my ability to express my freedom of speech on a website is being rescinded.  Because you have a problem with it personally.
No, I've not said that you can't use forums or posts.
So who sent you here then?
As you said, it's freedom of speech.  Right.  It's more about the content of what you've put.
So what have you got a problem with?
Some comment that you've said you're going to drag somebody out of an office, an MP, you're going to drag it out of an office into the street.
Based on a hypothetical situation.

Yeah, but all I'm asking, I'm not saying you can't use it, or you shouldn't be using it, I'm just asking you to be mindful about what you're putting on there.  All right.  In case it's deemed as inciting.
Yeah, let's put the situation into context, right?  So, based on something that may or may not happen, an action could be taken, right?  So how can you have a problem with that?
I'm not saying we've got a problem with it.  I've been asked to come speak to you to make you aware, okay, that your comments are visible online.
Oh, I know that.  I've been doing it for, what, 20 years?
Yeah.  And you've got every right to do that.
So why are you here then?
I'll just explain that to you.
It's the fact of what you said.
I can't do this alone.
Who wants to join me?
So it can be seen as sort of inciting something to happen.

Inciting what?  Inciting something based on an outcome that hasn't yet even been visualised.  No one knows whether it's going to happen or not.  If the government betrays the people, do you really think I'm going to be the only one?  How do you know?  Well, this is what I'm getting into.  This is what I'm getting into.  Because we need to get into it.  Because if you think about it, if Brexit is denied, there's not just going to be isolated pockets of violence.  The whole country is going to be inflamed.  You're talking 17.4 million people.  Yeah.  Do you think I'm going to be the only one?
Well, you've got your own comments and thoughts about it, haven't you?  That's fair enough.
I think a lot of people have.  Yeah.  And we've got the right to express it.
Yeah, of course you have.  I agree.
And you don't seem to get that.  No, I do.  Who sent you?
It's come from my inspector.
And the inspector is being ordered.  Is he taking it upon himself?  Who sent me?
Well, no, it's not.

It's not.  It's not.  Because you're coming round to my house, knocking on my door, asking me... You know, I should be careful, mindful of the comments I make online.  They're perfect within the law.  Right.  Aren't they?
But I've not seen you broke before, have I?  Otherwise I would have been dealing with it a different way.

I'm not saying you've committed any offences or committed a crime.  Let's say the worst happens.  The government betrays the people, right?  Because I don't trust them, loads of people don't trust them.  And I go round there with a group of people and we drag her out and we question her.  How can you do this to our country?  How can you call yourself a politician?  You know, people have voted you into power.  We've trusted you.  This is one of the strongest Brexit areas in the country.  And you've gone and done this.  How can you do that?  Right.  Well, we're going to decide now that we don't want you in our town anymore.  Leave.  Is that illegal?  No.  It's your thoughts, isn't it?  That's what you want.
Thoughts of the people.
I mean, I'm not threatening violence.  You're going to drag somebody out.

It's just how you've worded it.  If you're going to say, would you please come out so we can discuss it?  There's a difference between going in and physically dragging somebody out, which would be deemed as an assault.
I think the situation would radically change if that was going to be the case.
But again, I'm not saying you've done anything wrong, Stephen, at all.  I've just been asked to come and remind you about... the use of forums and social media, etc.
I don't need to be reminded of that.  I don't need you to come round to my house.
There's nothing else I need to discuss with you.

It's quite an interesting discussion when we've got a limited freedom of speech in this country.  It's been eroded all the time because people like you are taking orders from people who want it to be eroded.  You've got all these stupid laws that people can't speak their minds anymore.  You know what happens when people can't talk to each other?  Bad feelings bottle up inside you, and there's only a certain, you know, there's two things that are going to happen.  Either someone's going to explode and do something, and you guys are going to get involved, or they're just going to get depressed.  It's one of two, isn't it?
We're just here to keep the peace, aren't we?
You know what I mean?  Well, you're not here to keep the peace, because there's no peace has been... No, there hasn't.
There hasn't.  I'm not here for any other reason than to have a chat with you, that's all.  Well, I've not come to upset you.  I'll tell you that you can't do X, Y and Z.
It's sort of rings of the stars here, doesn't it?  You know?  Reductions of freedom.
If I've upset you, Stephen, I apologise.

Well, you haven't upset me, but the orders don't come from you.  You don't take it upon yourself to come here.  Someone's told you to come here.  Then you've got to ask the question, who asked the inspector to come here?  Was it the Home Office?
It's above my head as well now.
Or have you got a special division that's constantly monitoring speech online?
We will have, yeah.
You do?  What's it called?
Come on.  It's above my head.  I've no idea.  But there will be a unit that monitors comments and things.
Right, I'll do a Google on it then.  I'll find out.
All right.
Well, it was an interesting conversation, chaps.  See you later.
